analysis.title: Living Beer
analysis.author: Mark J Burkholder
analysis.logline: Three craft beer enthusiasts launch their dream brewery but must risk everything when their flagship beer becomes potentially explosive on opening day.

hook_clarity.note: Clear premise but lacks compelling urgency

freshness.note: Craft brewing is underexplored but execution is familiar

execution_independence.note: Relies heavily on insider knowledge and character chemistry

concept.justification: Small-scale entrepreneurial story in niche industry lacks broader appeal
concept.weakness_identified: Extremely narrow audience appeal - requires craft beer knowledge for investment

act_architecture.note: Clear setup and crisis but weak escalation

scene_necessity.note: Some scenes meander without clear purpose

momentum.note: Middle section lacks urgency until bottle crisis

payoff_delivery.note: Resolution feels convenient rather than earned

structure.justification: Basic three-act structure but lacks compelling dramatic escalation

goal_clarity.note: Ben wants brewery success but internal conflict unclear

active_agency.note: Often reactive, especially in distributor subplot

star_vehicle_quality.note: Passive role without compelling character hook

protagonist.justification: Ben lacks clear internal journey and compelling star qualities

character_distinction.note: Joe and Gus have distinct voices, Shana stands out

functional_purpose.note: Each serves story function while feeling real

castability.note: Shana especially offers strong character actor showcase

supporting_cast.justification: Shana's introduction is excellent character work with clear function

quotability.note: Industry-specific humor but no standout lines

translation_quality.note: Beer terminology might not translate but dialogue structure solid

dialogue.justification: Authentic craft beer dialogue with character-specific voices
page_citations: Page 2-3: Beer tasting sequence with technical terminology

obligatory_scenes.note: Has startup beats but lacks entrepreneurial drama stakes

audience_satisfaction.note: Pleasant but not particularly satisfying climax

genre_execution.justification: Competent workplace comedy execution without standout moments

voice_distinctiveness.note: Authentic industry voice but not unique storytelling

cultural_freshness.note: Very American craft beer culture specific

originality.justification: Fresh setting but conventional execution and narrow cultural appeal

cultural_resonance.rationale: American craft beer culture extremely niche in Mexico - entrepreneurial themes translate but specific context alienating

regional_casting_potential.rationale: Could recast with Mexican actors but story tied to American craft brewing scene

theatrical_appeal.rationale: Small-scale story better suited for streaming than theatrical experience

marketing_viability.rationale: Difficult to market to general Mexican audience - requires cultural translation

coproduction_potential.rationale: Story too culturally specific to American craft brewing for international appeal

critical_failures: Niche audience only - requires specific American craft beer knowledge
Culturally untranslatable - tied to American brewing scene

target_audience.note: Craft beer enthusiasts only - very niche

high_concept.note: Takes explanation of craft brewing culture

marketing_hook.note: Difficult to market beyond beer community

budget_return_ratio.note: Low budget but extremely limited audience

comparable_success.note: No successful craft brewing films for reference

structure_analysis.act_breaks: Setup through page 15, crisis at page 22, resolution page 30+
structure_analysis.pacing: Slow build with industry detail, rushed crisis resolution

characters.protagonist: Ben - brewery owner, unclear goals beyond success, lacks compelling arc
characters.antagonist: No clear antagonist - systemic industry challenges
supporting: Joe - passionate brewer with clear voice

standout_scenes.why: Excellent character introduction with clear competence and attitude
Authentic industry detail creates believable world

comparable_films.title: Chef
comparable_films.similarity: Small business entrepreneurial journey with craft focus
comparable_films.latam_performance: Food culture more universal than craft beer

target_audience.latam_audience_notes: Craft beer culture minimal in Mexico - would require significant cultural adaptation

budget_tier.justification: Single location brewery setting with minimal special requirements

strengths: Strong supporting character work especially Shana
assessment.recommendation_rationale: Weighted score of 4.95 falls below 5.5 threshold, multiple critical failures including niche-only audience and cultural untranslatability, CVS of 9 indicates serious commercial concerns.

film_now_assessment.lightning_test: Opening brewery sequence shows craft but lacks hook for general audience
film_now_assessment.career_risk_test: Absolutely not - too niche and culturally specific
film_now_assessment.legacy_potential: Limited to craft beer documentary interest

analysis.verdict_statement: While authentically crafted with genuine industry knowledge, this script serves an extremely narrow craft beer enthusiast audience that would struggle theatrically in Latin American markets. The culturally specific American brewing scene and passive protagonist create insurmountable commercial barriers.
analysis.executive_summary: Authentic craft brewery story with strong character work but fatal commercial flaws: niche American beer culture, passive protagonist, limited theatrical appeal, and narrow audience make this unsuitable for Latin American theatrical release.
